document.docAuthor: Dorchin, Netta, Mcevoy, Miles V., Dowling, Todd A., Abrahamson, Warren G. & Moore, Joseph G.
document.masterDocTitle: Revision of the goldenrod-galling Rhopalomyia species (Diptera: Cecidomyiidae) in North America

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of the goldenrod-galling Rhopalomyia species (Diptera: Cecidomyiidae) in North America

heading.emphasis:
Key to
Rhopalomyia
galls on North American goldenrods

paragraph.keyLead: 1 . Vegetative bud gall, fleshy or leafy, just above the ground or high above it................................................................ 2
-. Not fleshy; composed of many short leaves that form a rosette on apical or sometimes lateral shoot tips ................. 4

keyLead.keyStep:
3 . Smooth, bare gall on
Solidago juncea
either at the base of the plant, just above the ground, or on a growing shoot tip up to 60 cm above the ground; up to 4 cm in diameter (
Figs. 58â€“61
)
.................................. R. hirtipes
(Osten Sacken)

paragraph.keyLead:
- Spongy, spherical gall tightly surrounded by leaves, on growing shoot-tips of
Euthamia graminifolia
. Up to 6 cm in
- Galls found in summer and fall (late Julyâ€“early October); large and conspicuous...................................................... 6

5 . Gall found very close to the ground on
S. gigantea
sprouts and therefore cryptic despite its large size; usually con- taining 3â€“20 larval chambers; composed of many short and narrow leaves surrounded by 5â€“10 much longer leaves (
Fig. 74
)...................................................................................................................
R. capitata Felt
, spring generation

- Gall found at least 20 cm above the ground on young
S. altissima
,
S. rugosa
, or
S. canadensis
plants; usually con- taining 1â€“3 larval chambers; composed of 5â€“10 short leaves surrounded by several longer leaves. Hardly distin- guishable from normal growing shoot tips ( Figs. 70, 72 ).............................
R. solidaginis (Loew)
, spring generation

6 . Gall on
S. gigantea
, containing 5â€“30 larval chambers situated among uniformly distributed short leaves (
Fig. 75
)....
............................................................................................................................. R. capitata
Felt, summer generation

- Gall on
S. altissima
or
S. rugosa
, containing 3â€“10 larval chambers, each individually surrounded by a set of narrow leaves ( Figs. 71, 73 ) ....................................................................................
R. solidaginis (Loew)
, summer generation

8 . Tapered, bud-like, single-chambered galls in clusters on rhizomes of
S. juncea
..................................
R. bulbula Felt

- Cylindrical, multi-chambered galls in rhizomes of
S. altissima
........................................................
R. thompsoni Felt

- Galls on leaves or stems. If associated with inflorescence, then gall not developing inside a capitulum but situated on or among capitula........................................................................................................................................................ 12

11 . Cylindrical galls on
S. altissima
; slightly wider at base (
Figs. 56â€“57
)...........................
R. anthophila (Osten Sacken)

- Bulb-shaped galls, tapered at tip, on
S. altissima
and
S. fistulosa
...................................................
R. racemicola Felt

12 . Bulb-shaped, grayish galls with tapered apices, forming rosette-like aggregations on stems of
S. fistulosa .... R
. n. sp.

13 . Slender and elongate, green to purple galls with longitudinal stripes on
Euthamia
spp. .......................................... 14

- Conical, mostly green galls, sometimes with purple longitudinal stripes, on
Solidago
spp....................................... 15

14 . Gall carried on long stalk on leaves, stems, or inflorescences (
Figs. 84â€“85
)...................................
R. pedicellata Felt

- Gall sessile, without long stalk, on leaves, stems, or inflorescences (
Figs. 82â€“83
) .........................
R. fusiformae Felt

16 . On leaves of
S. juncea ;
sometimes with a tail-like extension on other side of leaf. May be found on leaves compos- ing rosette galls of
Asphondylia monacha
on this host (
Figs. 68â€“69
) .........................................
R. gina Dorchin
n.sp.

- On leaves or rarely stems of
S. gigantea
; without extension on other side of leaf. May be found on leaves composing rosette galls of
R. capitata
and
Dasineura folliculi
on this host (
